p: When an infectious cause is not present in croup, the clinical course is abbreviated, with the noticeable absence of the viral prodrome. This condition is frequently referred as “ spasmodic croup”, although episodic croup is a more appropriate term as it is typically triggered by an allergic etiology and often recurs [ 25]. Pediatric angioedema shares features with croup, but is often associated with facial or neck swelling that is acute in onset [ 26]. Rarely, an undetected foreign body may masquerade as acute croup. Although a viral prodrome may be absent, an unsuspecting physician may be drawn into an acute airway emergency due to commonality of symptoms [ 27].
